bug.author: pminervini
bug.summary: AdaGrad doesn't work with sparse operations on GPU in Eager mode
bug.description:
This happens with TensorFlow 1.12 and CUDA 9.0: $ python -c "import tensorflow as tf; print(tf.GIT_VERSION, tf.VERSION)" v1.12.0-0-ga6d8ffae09 1.12.0 Here's a minimal code snippet for reproducing the problem: #!/usr/bin/env python3 # -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
import tensorflow as tf import tensorflow.contrib.eager as tfe
tf.enable_eager_execution() var = tfe.Variable([0.0, 0.0, 0.0], name='tensor') optimizer = tf.train.AdagradOptimizer(learning_rate=0.1) with tf.GradientTape() as tape: fn = tf.nn.embedding_lookup(var, [0])[0] g = tape.gradient(fn, [var])[0] optimizer.apply_gradients(grads_and_vars=[(g, var)]) Here's the output, both on CPU and GPU: $ CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="" ./ada.py 2019-04-23 22:38:06.058069: I tensorflow/core/platform/cpu_feature_guard.cc:141] Your CPU supports instructions that this TensorFlow binary was not compiled to use: AVX2 FMA 2019-04-23 22:38:06.064824: E tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cuda_driver.cc:300] failed call to cuInit: CUDA_ERROR_NO_DEVICE: no CUDA-capable device is detected 2019-04-23 22:38:06.064853: I tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cuda_diagnostics.cc:163] retrieving CUDA diagnostic information for host: hamburg 2019-04-23 22:38:06.064858: I tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cuda_diagnostics.cc:170] hostname: hamburg 2019-04-23 22:38:06.064879: I tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cuda_diagnostics.cc:194] libcuda reported version is: 390.116.0 2019-04-23 22:38:06.064897: I tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cuda_diagnostics.cc:198] kernel reported version is: 390.116.0 2019-04-23 22:38:06.064902: I tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cuda_diagnostics.cc:305] kernel version seems to match DSO: 390.116.0
$ ./ada.py 2019-04-23 22:38:12.777841: I tensorflow/core/platform/cpu_feature_guard.cc:141] Your CPU supports instructions that this TensorFlow binary was not compiled to use: AVX2 FMA 2019-04-23 22:38:12.868632: I tensorflow/stream_executor/cuda/cuda_gpu_executor.cc:964] successful NUMA node read from SysFS had negative value (-1), but there must be at least one NUMA node, so returning NUMA node zero 2019-04-23 22:38:12.868990: I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/gpu/gpu_device.cc:1432] Found device 0 with properties: name: TITAN X (Pascal) major: 6 minor: 1 memoryClockRate(GHz): 1.531 pciBusID: 0000:02:00.0 totalMemory: 11.91GiB freeMemory: 9.38GiB 2019-04-23 22:38:12.869004: I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/gpu/gpu_device.cc:1511] Adding visible gpu devices: 0 2019-04-23 22:38:13.675859: I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/gpu/gpu_device.cc:982] Device interconnect StreamExecutor with strength 1 edge matrix: 2019-04-23 22:38:13.675884: I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/gpu/gpu_device.cc:988] 0 2019-04-23 22:38:13.675889: I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/gpu/gpu_device.cc:1001] 0: N 2019-04-23 22:38:13.676041: I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/gpu/gpu_device.cc:1115] Created TensorFlow device (/job:localhost/replica:0/task:0/device:GPU:0 with 9063 MB memory) -> physical GPU (device: 0, name: TITAN X (Pascal), pci bus id: 0000:02:00.0, compute capability: 6.1) Traceback (most recent call last): File "./ada.py", line 17, in <module> optimizer.apply_gradients(grads_and_vars=[(g, var)]) File "/home/anaconda/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tensorflow/python/training/optimizer.py", line 610, in apply_gradients update_ops.append(processor.update_op(self, grad)) File comments.comment: An easy fix is placing variables on CPU, but that harms efficiency quite a lot. Adam works just fine, but at the moment I really need AdaGrad. What's the best way to fix this?

I was able to reproduce the error in TF 1.13 using google colab with gpu accelerator. The script executes successfully using cpu. Similar issue <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/22042>#22042</denchmark-link>

Adagrad doesn't work with sparse operations on the GPU in graph mode either, but TF's default placement policy will run the update on the CPU without telling you. In eager execution you need to explicitly put the variables in the CPU for now, by declaring the variable in a with tf.device('cpu:0'): block.

Are you satisfied with the resolution of your issue? <denchmark-link:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfaP12TRhd9xSxjXZjcZFNXPGk4kc1-qMdv3gc6bEP90vY1ew/viewform?entry.85265664=Yes&entry.2137816233=28090>Yes</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-link:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfaP12TRhd9xSxjXZjcZFNXPGk4kc1-qMdv3gc6bEP90vY1ew/viewform?entry.85265664=No&entry.2137816233=28090>No</denchmark-link>

Adagrad doesn't work with sparse operations on the GPU in graph mode either, but TF's default placement policy will run the update on the CPU without telling you.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/alextp>@alextp</denchmark-link> why this? I'm currently using but it's insanely slow compared to Adam. Is there any hope this will change in the future?

The core operation in sparse adagrad just hasn't been implemented on GPU <denchmark-link:#></denchmark-link>
On Mon, Apr 29, 2019 at 11:03 AM Pasquale Minervini < ***@***.***> wrote: Adagrad doesn't work with sparse operations on the GPU in graph mode either, but TF's default placement policy will run the update on the CPU without telling you.
@alextp <https://github.com/alextp> why this? I'm currently using with tf.device('cpu:0'): but it's insanely slow compared to Adam.

-- - Alex
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/alextp>@alextp</denchmark-link> is it desirable to have? I may be able to put some cycles on this in June, where should I start?

Yes it's desirable to have. The place to start is <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/kernels/training_ops.cc>https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/kernels/training_ops.cc</denchmark-link>
which defines the kernels for the optimizers. You'll see the kernels for the sparse updates are only implemented for CPU right now. To make GPU kernels for them we'd need to use a functor which knows how to do the scatter operation implied in sparse updates, calling it after calling the eigen computation representing the logic in adagrad (and other sparse optimizers). <denchmark-link:#></denchmark-link>
On Tue, Apr 30, 2019 at 6:50 AM Pasquale Minervini ***@***.***> wrote: @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> is it desirable to have? I may be able to put some cycles on this in June, where should I start?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/alextp>@alextp</denchmark-link> Hi Alex, I attempted this a while back but it seemed one would need to aggregate the accumulators belonging to the same variable entry first before updating that entry, and this requires some sort of group by or unique operation that cannot be efficiently done with CUDA (in fact tf.unique in cuda mode seems to be happening on cpu). Maybe that's why it's never implemented?
It's possible to do sparse updates without the aggregation.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/alextp>@alextp</denchmark-link> Could you give some pointers/references on how to do that? My understanding is that unless the the SlicedIndex has unique indices, one would need to invoke the _deduplicate_indexed_slices function before updating the variable/accumulator. Internally that function calls tf.unique. I wouldn't mind callig tf.unique on vocab ids, but on embedding gradient it's a bit expensive with host/device IO cost, since tf.unique is only available on CPU. Calling tf.unique in the forward pass on each individual embedding feature is also not enough to ensure row uniqueness in the gradient, when we have shared embedding features. Their respective y_grads are currently aggregated by means of aggregate_indexed_slices_gradients, which essentially concatenates the IndexedSlices.

I just meant that some algorithms (like plain sgd, or some variants of momentum) have linear updates which can be robust when repeated indices are present. Otherwise your point about indexed slices aggregation requiring new calls to unique is valid. <denchmark-link:#></denchmark-link>
On Sun, Jul 19, 2020 at 7:47 PM e-commerce-search ***@***.***> wrote: @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> Could you give some pointers/references on how to do that?
My understanding is that unless the the SlicedIndex has unique indices, one would need to invoke the _deduplicate_indexed_slices function before updating the variable/accumulator. Internally that function calls tf.unique. I wouldn't mind callig tf.unique on vocab ids, but on embedding gradient it's a bit expensive with host/device IO cost, since tf.unique is only available on CPU. Calling tf.unique in the forward pass on each individual embedding feature is also not enough to ensure row uniqueness in the gradient, when we have shared embedding features. Their respective y_grads will be aggregated by means of aggregate_indexed_slices_gradients, which essentially concatenates the IndexedSlices.
Of course one could do away with SharedEmbedding and use tf.gather to slice out the components directly, but this would be very hacky and quite a departure from the current feature_columns framework.

I got the exact same issue today with tensorflow 2 when i was working on something similar and coincidentally you also encountered similar issue <denchmark-link:https://github.com/pminervini>@pminervini</denchmark-link> . I am currently using the following workaround and it seems to run fast on GPU with adagrad: <denchmark-code>import tensorflow as tf import tensorflow.contrib.eager as tfe
tf.enable_eager_execution() var = tfe.Variable([0.0, 0.0, 0.0], name='tensor') optimizer = tf.train.AdagradOptimizer(learning_rate=0.1) with tf.GradientTape() as tape: fn = tf.nn.embedding_lookup(var, [0])[0] workaround = fn + 0.0 * (tf.reduce_sum(var)) g = tape.gradient(workaround, [var])[0] optimizer.apply_gradients(grads_and_vars=[(g, var)]) </denchmark-code>
I guess the addition of 0 should have no affect on the gradients.

Thanks for the update! My workaround was slightly different - switching to PyTorch <denchmark-link:#></denchmark-link>
